questions.text:
A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient was riding a motorcycle through a traffic intersection when he was hit by a pickup truck at high speed and was thrown from the bike. He did not sustain any head injuries or lose consciousness. Upon arrival, temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 122/71 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination reveals diffuse bruising and lacerations. A portion of the right chest wall is noted to move outward during expiration and inwards on inspiration. No abdominal tenderness or distention is noted. Imaging is ordered and reveals the following:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Insertion of a right-sided chest tube
Transfusion with packed red blood cells
Surgical reduction and fixation of fractured ribs

questions.solution:
This patient presents following a motor vehicle accident with paradoxical movements of the right chest wall and multiple broken ribs on imaging. Together, these findings are concerning for flail chest. Given he is hemodynamically stable and without signs of active bleeding, the next best step includes adequate analgesia.

A flail chest occurs when three or more ribs fracture in two or more places, allowing a segment of the thoracic wall to move freely. During normal inspiration, the thoracic wall expands outwards and increases its diameter, whereas during expiration, it decreases its diameter to expel air. With flail chest, paradoxical movement occurs such that during inspiration, the free segment moves inward, and during expiration, it moves outward. A flail chest is an extremely painful injury and may induce hypoventilation due to a patient’s reluctance to breathe adequately through the pain.

Management wise, the first step is to ensure adequate pain control and provide supplemental oxygen if needed. Positive pressure ventilation can be used to force the flail chest segment out during inspiration, should the patient decompensate. In extreme cases, surgical repair of the fractures may be necessary, such as in patients with severe chest wall instability or fracture nonunion.  



Option Analysis

✅ Administration of intravenous morphine  :
Correct: See main explanation.  
❌ Insertion of a right-sided chest tube  :
Incorrect: This patient was involved in a motor vehicle accident and imaging reveals four consecutive rib fractures, which is concerning for a flail chest. This patient does not have evidence of pneumothorax, hemothorax, or significant pleural effusions, and as a result, insertion of a chest tube is not necessary.  
❌ Transfusion with packed red blood cells  :
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically stable and has no signs of acute bleeding, such as abdominal tenderness due to splenic rupture or fluid accumulation within the chest due to hemothorax. As such, a blood transfusion is not indicated at this time.  
❌ Perform endotracheal intubation  :
Incorrect: Patients with flail chest may develop respiratory failure and require endotracheal intubation. This patient, however, has a normal oxygen saturation on room air. Should the patient’s oxygen saturation drop, non-invasive methods (e.g., nasal cannula, continuous positive airway pressure) should be attempted prior to proceeding to intubation.  
❌ Surgical reduction and fixation of fractured ribs  :
Incorrect: Surgical repair of a flail chest is reserved for severe cases. This includes patients who cannot be weaned from mechanical ventilation, have severe chest wall instability, or have persistent pain secondary to fracture malunion. In contrast, this patient is hemodynamically stable with adequate oxygen saturation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a stab wound to the right chest. Per EMS, the patient was involved in an altercation at home and was stabbed over the right chest wall. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 120/71 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 92% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates diminished breath sounds over the right chest and moderate tachypnea without evidence of tracheal deviation. Based on the diagram below, which of the following best identifies the appropriate site for procedural intervention to manage this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with respiratory distress, reduced breath sounds in the right lung, and a history of penetrating chest trauma. These findings are consistent with a traumatic pneumothorax.   

In traumatic pneumothorax, air can pass from the outside atmosphere into the pleural space, resulting in a compressive force on the lung. Patients typically present with tachypnea, tachycardia, hypoxia, diminished breath sounds, and signs of trauma.  

In the absence of tension physiology (discussed below), patients with pneumothorax should have a tube thoracostomy performed, with the placement of a chest tube on the affected side at the fourth or fifth intercostal space, midaxillary line. This landmark can be approximated by following the nipple line to the midaxillary line on the affected side. With the correct placement, a gush of air is often audible. Subsequent lung re-expansion leads to improvement in oxygenation, heart rate, and blood pressure.  

When performing this procedure, care should be taken to identify the appropriate anatomic space. If placed too high, there is a risk of damage to the brachial plexus and subclavian vasculature. If placed too low, there is an increased risk of damage to intra-abdominal organs. Furthermore, the tube should be inserted over the superior aspect of the rib to avoid damaging the intercostal vessels and nerves (which run along the inferior aspect of the ribs).    

Patients may present with evidence of tension physiology, which includes tracheal deviation, jugular venous distension, and hemodynamic instability. A tension pneumothorax is emergently treated with needle decompression by placing a large-bore angiocatheter (14-16 Gauge) at the second or third intercostal space at the midclavicular line.  

Option Analysis

✅ Site A:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Site B:
Incorrect: Site B refers to the third intercostal space at the midaxillary line, which is too high for chest tube placement. Entering the chest cavity at this anatomic landmark increases the risk for trauma to the brachial plexus and subclavian vasculature. 
❌ Site C:
Incorrect: Site C refers to the second intercostal space at the midclavicular line, which is an appropriate site for needle decompression of a tension pneumothorax. However, based on this patient’s clinical presentation, there is no evidence of tension physiology. 
❌ Site D:
Incorrect: Site D refers to the eighth intercostal space at the midaxillary line, which is too low for chest tube placement. Placement of a chest tube at this site increases the risk of diaphragmatic and liver injury. 
❌ Site E:
Incorrect: Site E refers to the fourth intercostal space at the midclavicular line, which is not a site for chest tube placement.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to fever and a productive cough for three days. The patient has multiple comorbidities and several past surgeries but is unable to recall the details at this time. Her temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), blood pressure is 165/89 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, and respiratory rate is 21/min. Physical examination demonstrates a well-healed, midline, sternal scar and rales in the bilateral lungs. A chest x-ray is ordered, revealing a focal consolidation in the right lower lobe and multiple radiopaque wires embedded in the sternum. Given these findings, the patient’s past history is most likely notable for which of the following?

choices.text: Placement of stent in left anterior descending artery
Treatment of dissection in the descending aorta
Surgical reduction and fixation of flail chest

questions.solution:
This patient has evidence of a previous median sternotomy, given a midline chest scar and imaging demonstrating multiple sternal wires. Among the answer choices, only coronary artery bypass surgery is typically performed via a median sternotomy.

A median sternotomy is a surgical approach in which the sternum is split in the median plane and retracted. This allows surgeons to access organs within the thoracic cavity, such as the heart and lungs. Procedures that may involve a median sternotomy include heart transplantation, surgical repair of congenital cardiac defects, and pneumonectomy. Following surgery, the two halves of the sternum are joined together using wires or sutures.  



Option Analysis

❌ Placement of stent in left anterior descending artery  :
Incorrect: Stents are often placed for the treatment of ST-elevated myocardial infarctions. Stents are overwhelmingly placed via a percutaneous approach, wherein the stent is introduced into a blood vessel and guided towards the coronary arteries. Stent placement would not commonly result in a midline chest scar or presence of surgical wires on x-ray imaging.  
❌ Repair of esophageal perforation:
Incorrect: An esophageal perforation can occur due to spontaneous perforation (e.g. Boerhaave syndrome), ingestion of foreign objects, or trauma. If the perforation site lies within the thoracic cavity, a left or right thoracotomy is performed. A midline sternotomy would not typically be performed to treat esophageal perforation.  
❌ Treatment of dissection in the descending aorta  :
Incorrect: Dissection of the descending aorta is managed medically with beta-blockers. The condition would not warrant surgical intervention or a midline sternotomy.  
❌ Surgical reduction and fixation of flail chest  :
Incorrect: Severe cases of flail chest may require surgical repair of the broken ribs. Postoperatively, imaging may reveal metallic plates and screws along the fractured ribs. This patient’s imaging and physical exam findings are more suggestive of a midline sternotomy, which is not used in the treatment of rib fractures.  
✅ Coronary artery bypass grafting  :
Correct: See main explanation.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. The patient was driving home from a party when he crashed into the concrete barrier lining the highway. He did not lose consciousness. Upon arrival, the patient is yelling in pain and holding his chest and abdomen. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 108/72 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. The patient is alert, in distress, and speaking in full sentences. Physical examination reveals diffuse pain over the anterior chest and abdomen. Strength and sensation are intact in all extremities. Laboratory testing is notable for an elevated blood alcohol level. A single-view chest x-ray is obtained and is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient’s condition?

questions.solution:
This patient was involved in a motor vehicle accident, and chest-x-ray reveals free air beneath the diaphragm–consistent with pneumoperitoneum. The patient should undergo an urgent exploratory laparotomy to evaluate for a traumatic perforation.  

Chest x-rays are typically the first-line imaging modality when a pulmonary or mediastinal etiology is suspected. Common indications for chest x-ray include chest pain, shortness of breath, and cough. It is also used as a part of a standard trauma evaluation.

Option Analysis

❌ Needle thoracostomy:
Incorrect: A needle thoracostomy should be performed in the setting of a tension pneumothorax. Imaging will reveal collapse of the affected lung and contralateral shift of the mediastinum. These findings are absent on this patient’s chest radiograph.
❌ Administration of fomepizole:
Incorrect: Fomepizole can be administered to treat ethylene glycol or methanol poisoning. However, it is not routinely used in cases of ethanol toxicity. 
❌ Endotracheal intubation :
Incorrect: This patient does not demonstrate evidence of airway compromise as he is speaking in clear, full sentences.  
❌ Placement of figure-of-eight brace:
Incorrect: A figure-of-eight brace can be used in the treatment of a clavicular fracture, but the bilateral clavicles appear unremarkable in this patient's chest x-ray. However, imaging does reveal pneumoperitoneum, which should be managed with an exploratory laparotomy. 
✅ Exploratory laparotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the emergency department after being stabbed in the chest. The patient's primary survey is notable for decreased breath sounds over the right chest. Secondary survey reveals a single stab wound to the right lateral thorax, tracheal deviation, and jugular venous distension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 126/min, and blood pressure is 77/42 mmHg. Respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Which of the following best describes the correct anatomic space for emergent intervention to manage this patient's condition?

choices.text: Fourth or fifth intercostal space midaxillary line
Sternal head and clavicular head of sternocleidomastoid

questions.solution:
This patient has decreased breath sounds, tracheal deviation, jugular venous distension, and hemodynamic instability in the setting of a stab wound to the right chest. He most likely has a tension pneumothorax. This clinical diagnosis must be recognized rapidly and treated by placing a large-bore angiocatheter (14-16G) at the second or third intercostal space at the midclavicular line.  

With correct placement, a gush of air is often audible, with subsequent lung reexpansion and improvement in oxygenation, heart rate, and blood pressure. Tube thoracostomy should always follow needle thoracostomy, with placement of a chest tube on the affected side at the fourth or fifth intercostal space midaxillary line.  

Tension pneumothorax occurs in many clinical scenarios such as in penetrating trauma, blunt trauma, and mechanically ventilated patients. Regardless of the cause, the clinical features remain the same. Patients will develop dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, reduced breath sounds over the affected lung, and hyperresonance to percussion. In severe cases, patients can develop tracheal deviation. Patients can also have hypotension and elevated jugular venous pulsations secondary to compression of the heart and vena cava.

Option Analysis

✅ Second intercostal space midclavicular line  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fourth or fifth intercostal space midaxillary line:
Incorrect: The fourth or fifth intercostal space describes the correct anatomic site for chest tube placement. While chest tubes are the definitive treatment for a pneumothorax, rapid intervention with needle thoracostomy should be performed first in patients with a tension pneumothorax to relieve pressure on mediastinal structures.
❌ Left lateral subxiphoid space:
Incorrect: A left lateral subxiphoid approach is often used in emergent pericardiocentesis to treat patients with cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade can present with the Beck triad (hypotension, jugular venous distention, and muffled heart sounds). However, it would not present with hyperresonance or tracheal deviation.  
❌ Sternal head and clavicular head of sternocleidomastoid:
Incorrect: Central venous access is commonly obtained by cannulating the internal jugular vein, which is found above the clavicle and between the two heads of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Central venous access is obtained for the administration of vasopressors, large volume transfusions, frequent blood draws, hemodynamic monitoring, and emergent dialysis. However, obtaining central venous access would not help treat this patient’s tension pneumothorax.
❌ Mid-infraclavicular space  :
Incorrect: The infraclavicular approach is another method to obtain central venous access. However, this technique has fallen out of favor since it does not allow for ultrasound confirmation of successful line placement.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining a gunshot wound (GSW) to the chest. Per paramedics, the patient was shot several times over the right chest. He was initially alert and anxious but became more obtunded en route to the emergency department. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 137/min, respirations are 7/min, blood pressure is 71/40 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 85% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is noted to have three GSWs to the anterior chest with corresponding exit wounds on the back. Breath sounds are absent over the right lung. The trachea is midline, and there is no jugular venous distension. A Mayo stand is subsequently prepared for emergency tube thoracostomy. Which of the following best describes the correct anatomic placement for tube thoracostomy?

choices.text: Fourth intercostal space, midaxillary line, superior aspect of the rib
Second intercostal space, midclavicular line, inferior aspect of the rib
Second intercostal space, midclavicular line, superior aspect of the rib
Fourth intercostal space, midaxillary line, inferior aspect of the rib
Third intercostal space, midaxillary line, superior aspect of the rib

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features concerning for a traumatic hemothorax, thereby necessitating an emergent tube thoracostomy. The correct anatomic location for performing tube thoracostomy is at the fourth or fifth intercostal space, mid-axillary line, on the superior aspect of the rib.   

Tube thoracostomy, or chest tube placement, is a standard emergency medicine and trauma critical care procedure. Indications for tube thoracostomy include pneumothorax, hemothorax, extension of mediastinal air, air leak following pulmonary resection, and management of bronchopleural fistula. Care must be taken during placement to avoid injury to surrounding anatomic structures.  

Specific anatomic considerations include ensuring placement within the triangle of safety, which is formed anteriorly by the lateral border of the pectoralis major muscle, posteriorly by the lateral wall of the latissimus dorsi muscle, and inferiorly by the 5th intercostal space (or a horizontal line from the nipple). In addition, care should be taken when placing the tube, as it should be advanced over the superior aspect of the rib to avoid damage to the inferior neurovascular bundle. For pneumothoraces, the tube should advance superiorly into the chest cavity. In contrast, for hemothoraces, the tube should be advanced inferiorly into the chest cavity for adequate drainage.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Fourth intercostal space, midaxillary line, superior aspect of the rib:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Second intercostal space, midclavicular line, inferior aspect of the rib:
Incorrect: This anatomic site references the incorrect location for needle decompression. A needle and catheter should be placed on the superior aspect of the rib to avoid damage to the intercostal vasculature and nerve. 
❌ Second intercostal space, midclavicular line, superior aspect of the rib:
Incorrect: This anatomic site references the correct location for needle decompression. However, this question is about tube thoracostomy. 
❌ Fourth intercostal space, midaxillary line, inferior aspect of the rib:
Incorrect: This anatomic site references the incorrect location for tube thoracostomy. A chest tube should be placed over the superior aspect of the rib to avoid damage to the intercostal vasculature and nerve. 
❌ Third intercostal space, midaxillary line, superior aspect of the rib:
Incorrect: Placement of a chest tube in this anatomic space is more likely to result in iatrogenic harm to structures such as the brachial plexus and subclavian vasculature.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department after falling from a ladder. The patient was standing on a six-foot ladder when he suddenly lost balance, fell, and landed on his right side. He currently reports pain in the shoulder and over the right rib cage. He does not take any medications and does not have other medical conditions. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 132/63 mmHg. Respiratory rate is 20/min and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds at the right lung base, as well as a 5 cm x 5 cm area of ecchymosis over the lateral rib cage. A chest CT is obtained, and the results are shown below:

Image reproduced from

Which of the following best describes the correct anatomic space for emergent intervention to manage this patient's condition?

choices.text: Fourth or fifth intercostal space midaxillary line
Fifth or sixth intercostal space midaxillary line
Sternal head and clavicular head of sternocleidomastoid

questions.solution:
This patient sustained blunt trauma to the chest, and the CT scan demonstrates fluid in the right pleural cavity. He most likely has a hemothorax, which should be managed with a tube thoracostomy.  

A hemothorax refers to blood in the pleural cavity. The condition is commonly associated with blunt or penetrating thoracic trauma. It is most commonly caused by injury to lung parenchyma, but it can also result from injury to the internal mammary arteries or the intercostal arteries.  

In most hemothoraces, bleeding is venous and manifests with mild tachypnea, borderline hypoxia, and tachycardia. If arterial injury occurs, hemorrhage into the pleural may become severe, resulting in hemodynamic instability and tension physiology.  

Hemothorax is diagnosed primarily by an upright chest x-ray, which will show a meniscus of fluid blunting the costophrenic angle and tracking up the pleural margins of the chest wall. Chest CT can also be used and will demonstrate fluid in the pleural cavity.  

Management of a hemothorax involves tube thoracostomy, which entails placing a chest tube at the 4th or 5th intercostal space midaxillary line. Afterwards, small hemothoraces (immediate drainage < 1500 mL and continued output < 200 mL/h over 4 hours) can be managed with observation. Large hemothoraces (if immediate drainage > 1500 mL and continued output > 200 mL/h over 4 hours) should be managed with an urgent thoracotomy.

Option Analysis

✅ Fourth or fifth intercostal space midaxillary line:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Second intercostal space midclavicular line  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes correct placement for emergent needle decompression in the setting of a tension pneumothorax. This patient does not have physical examination findings (e.g., tracheal deviation, jugular venous distention) or imaging findings (e.g. mediastinal shift) consistent with a tension pneumothorax. Instead, the imaging findings reveal fluid accumulation in the right chest.
❌ Fifth or sixth intercostal space midaxillary line  :
Incorrect: The patient has a right hemothorax. A tube thoracostomy should be performed to drain the blood. However, it would be inappropriate to perform the procedure at this anatomic location, as it places the patient at risk for diaphragmatic or intra-abdominal injury.
❌ Sternal head and clavicular head of sternocleidomastoid  :
Incorrect: Central venous access is commonly obtained by cannulating the internal jugular vein, which is found above the clavicle and between the two heads of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Central venous access is obtained for the administration of vasopressors, large volume transfusions, frequent blood draws, hemodynamic monitoring, and emergent dialysis. However, obtaining central venous access would not help treat this patient’s hemothorax.
❌ Mid-infraclavicular space  :
Incorrect: The infraclavicular approach is another method to obtain central venous access. However, this patient is hemodynamically stable and does not need central venous access. Moreover, the infraclavicular approach has fallen out of favor since it does not allow for ultrasound confirmation of successful line placement.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 2-day history of progressive sore throat, dysphagia, and dyspnea. He has not been able to eat or drink due to severe pain. He reports a fever of 38.7°C (101.7°F). His medical history is significant for poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, and a 25-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), blood pressure is 103/69 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. On physical examination, he appears uncomfortable and is leaning forward with his hands on his knees, drooling, and speaking in a muffled voice. His neck appears swollen and is diffusely tender, and he is holding it in a flexed position. He has diffuse pharyngeal erythema on oropharyngeal exam, and no tongue deviation. The lateral neck x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Image taken from Wiki.doc

choices.text: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, sore throat, neck pain and swelling, dysphagia, muffled voice, dyspnea, and tripod positioning along with thickening of the prevertebral space on lateral neck x-ray. This clinical presentation is consistent with the diagnosis of retropharyngeal abscess and acute airway obstruction.
 

Retropharyngeal abscesses typically occur in adults with diabetes or immunosuppression. They can result from the spread of a local infection, often from the oropharynx, or from penetrating trauma to the posterior pharyngeal wall. The prevertebral space can become infected with abscess formation. Evaluation includes neck imaging which often shows widening of the prevertebral space and visualization of the abscess. Management includes prompt antimicrobial therapy and possible surgical drainage. An untreated or unrecognized retropharyngeal abscess can lead to serious complications, such as airway obstruction, aspiration pneumonia, mediastinitis, and sepsis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Retropharyngeal abscess:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Foreign body aspiration:
Incorrect: Foreign body aspiration may cause dyspnea and respiratory distress. This patient with a sore throat, painful neck, painful swallowing, systemic signs of infection, and a widened prevertebral space on lateral neck x-ray more likely has a retropharyngeal abscess.  
❌ Epiglottitis:
Incorrect: Although epiglottitis may cause sore throat, dyspnea, systemic signs of infection, and the need to sit in a tripod position, a thumbprint sign would be seen on lateral neck imaging and not a widened prevertebral space which is consistent with a diagnosis of retropharyngeal abscess.  
❌ Peritonsillar abscess:
Incorrect: While a peritonsillar abscess may cause a sore throat and muffled voice, it also typically presents with findings of uvular deviation and unilateral tonsillar swelling.  
❌ Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: While the patient's smoking history increases his risk for developing head and neck cancer, the acuity of his symptoms and systemic signs of infection suggest an infectious etiology rather than a malignancy.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family due to the sudden onset of difficulty breathing. He was eating a steak dinner when he began coughing violently. Past medical history is significant for Parkinson’s disease. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 135/86 mmHg, pulse is 126/min, and respirations are 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 88% on 15L non-rebreather. On physical examination, the patient appears anxious, is using accessory respiratory muscles, and has nostril flaring. Pulmonary auscultation is significant for decreased breath sound over the right lung fields with high-pitched wheezing. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Chest x-ray reveals hyperinflation of the right lung and mediastinal shift to the left. Bag-valve mask ventilation is initiated, and oxygen saturation improves to 93%. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the chest with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of Parkinson’s disease is brought by his family due to the sudden onset of coughing while eating followed by dyspnea. On physical examination, he has decreased breath sounds over the right lung fields with high-pitched wheezing, and signs of respiratory compromise. This clinical presentation, along with hyperinflation of the right lung and shift of the mediastinum to the left seen on imaging, is highly suggestive of foreign body aspiration with acute airway obstruction of the right main bronchus.

In addition to securing the airway with bag-valve-mask ventilation, the best next step in managing this patient is to perform a flexible bronchoscopy for diagnosis and retrieval of the foreign body. Flexible bronchoscopy can be used to remove subglottic or tracheal foreign bodies. Post-removal management involves treatment of post-removal subglottic edema with parenteral glucocorticoids, nebulized epinephrine, and helium-oxygen or heliox therapy while monitoring for potential complications, such as pneumothorax or bronchial injury. For patients with recurrent foreign body aspiration, particularly those with predisposing conditions such as Parkinson’s or Alzheimer’s disease, preventative measures, including dietary modifications, and swallowing therapy are indicated.

Initially, high-flow oxygen should be provided to all patients experiencing airway obstruction. In cases where patients are unable to maintain adequate oxygenation despite supplemental oxygen, bag-valve-mask ventilation or mechanical ventilation is indicated. Direct laryngoscopy and bronchoscopy are further non-operative techniques that allow for visualization and potential removal of the obstructing object. If non-operative measures prove to be ineffective surgical management may be indicated. Cricothyroidotomy, an emergency procedure, involves making a surgical incision into the cricothyroid membrane to establish an airway. It is typically utilized with life-threatening supraglottic airway obstruction, if intubation is unsuccessful after 3 attempts, or if oxygen saturation cannot be maintained > 90%. Tracheostomy, on the other hand, involves creating an opening in the trachea and is generally employed for longer-term management of airway obstruction when it is expected to persist.  

Option Analysis

✅ Flexible bronchoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CT scan of the chest with IV contrast:
Incorrect: Although a CT scan of the chest may be useful for confirming the diagnosis, it should not delay intervention with flexible bronchoscopy in the case of acute airway obstruction.  
❌ Cricothyroidotomy:
Incorrect: Cricothyroidotomy may become necessary if less invasive methods of ventilation fail to maintain oxygen saturation >90% or are contraindicated. This patient’s oxygen saturation is maintained above 90% with bag-valve-mask ventilation. Therefore flexible bronchoscopy can be performed next.  
❌ Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Incorrect: Although securing the airway takes priority in the management of acute airway obstruction, this patient’s oxygen saturation is maintained above 90% with bag-valve-mask ventilation. Therefore, flexible bronchoscopy can be performed next.  
❌ Intravenous corticosteroid and nebulized epinephrine:
Incorrect: IV corticosteroids and nebulized epinephrine are indicated in the management of subglottic edema in the setting of foreign body aspiration. It is not the best next step in the management of this patient as retrieval of the foreign body with flexible bronchoscopy takes priority.

A pharmacist compares several inhaled anesthetic agents in a series of experiments. The obtained results are summarized below. Which of the following best describes the property of halothane when compared to that nitrous oxide?
 
Table 1: Properties of different inhaled anesthetic agents

Blood-gas partition coefficient  
Brain-blood partition coefficient  
Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)
Nitrous oxide
